results.title: The Rooftop hopper = Halfaouine
results.creator_credit: Cine Tele Films, France Media, Scarabee and Ferid Boughedir
results.brief_description: Noura (Selim Boughedir) lives in Halfaouine, a popular quarter of the old city of Tunis. Like many adolescent boys he wants to know more about women and he increases his knowledge through his trips to the local bathhouse with his mother. The interaction between Noura, his mother, and other women in the bathhouse makes for comic moments as well as a sharp insight into relations between the sexes in the Arab community. Cast includes Mohamed Driss, Mustafa Aduenie and Rabia Ben Abdallah. Included as part of Africa 95, a nationwide season of the arts of Africa, screened throughout the United Kingdom in 1995.

results.title: The Romantic period
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English Literature”.
Illustrates the literary and political revolution that occurred in the early part of the nineteenth century. Dramatised selections from Burns, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Blake, Byron, Shelley, Keats and Scott reveal the individuality and independence of spirit of England’s Romantic writers.

results.title: The Romans in Britain
results.brief_description: Three part series covering the centuries beginning and ending the Roman occupation of early Britain. The series traces the social, political and cultural impact of the Roman Empire on early Britain and the future of the country and investigates various historical landmarks and events that signal the significance of the Roman presence and influence. Other subjects discussed include culinary, architectural, religious and community planning traditions of Roman Britain, all illustrated through interviews with historians, archaeologists and re-enactment troups as well as investigation of artifacts and characteristics and representations of this period in contemporary England. “Roman’s in Britain” is a comprehensive investigation of the history of Rome and of Britain, and their mutually influential position in classical history.

group_works.title: Hadrian's Wall: the edge of empire

results.title: The Romans
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Presents the origins, growth and collapse of the Roman Empire. Describes how the Romans imitated the greek ideal of the city state and how they expanded over a period of 400 years, emerging as the ruling force of the world. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: The Romanian solution
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Jonathan Stedall and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Long Search”.
Even under the communist regime of 1977 it was estimated that 80% of the Romanian population were members of the Orthodox church. The Orthodox church lays claim to an uninterrupted 2000 years of unfragmented Christianity, a Christianity which gives great importance to the symbolic, particularly in the form of icons, which are windows into heaven. This is because the Orthodox believe that words do not suffice to convey the real meaning of what we feel. The program includes church ceremonies, and particularly the celebration of Easter.

results.title: The Romance of Runnibede
results.creator_credit: Phillips Film Productions and Scott R. Dunlap
results.brief_description: Filmed in Sydney interiors and south-east Queensland locations, this melodrama is based on one of the incidents in Steele Rudd’s book involving the kidnapping of a woman from the family cattle station by Aborigines who believe that she is their ‘great white queen’. Beset by production problems and discord and marred by the inadequate performances of the two male leads, Runnibede was reshaped by an imported American director for the international market. The Aborigines in effect become head-hunters from Hollywood’s darkest Africa mythology. Cast includes Eva Novak, Gordon Collingridge, Claude Saunders and Dunstan Webb. Restored on video using original tinted nitrate reels of the film.

results.title: The Romance of glassmaking. Part 1
results.brief_description: Glassmaking is an art that was practised by the ancient Egyptians. Made since 1680 at the White Friars Glass Works, England, the practice is still carried on by craftsmen in the works of James Powell & Sons (White Friars) at Wealdstone. Film demonstrates the art from the clay preparation through to the finished object.

results.title: The Romance of brown coal
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Illustrates how brown coal has been formed in the Latrobe Valley. Also shows the mining of brown coal and the conveyance of the coal from the open cut to the power house and briquetting plant.
